The simple crux of playing Left 4 Dead is that Left 4 Dead 2 exists. The sequel has more of just about everything, with nearly all of this game's content included. This game has fewer campaigns, fewer extra modes, and fewer weapons (including a complete lack of melee weapons). I've seen some favor this game for its atmosphere. Indeed, Left 4 Dead takes itself more seriously, skewer closer to its horror inspiration. But I suppose that's not why I play either Left 4 Dead game, especially given that both are multiplayer-oriented experiences. When playing with friends, much of the tonal nuance is inevitably lost.
I will concede that, from my estimation, this game's default lighting solution is far more playable than the sequel's. You'll still find plenty of pitch-black rooms, but it's not as prohibitive.
If I can praise anything unequivocally, it's this game's opening cinematic, which expertly introduces you to so many key gameplay elements, such as the various special infected to expect and the car alarms.
As I see it, there's no reason to play this game when you can get basically all of its content in the sequel, on top of everything it adds. This game has few advantages over its successor to justify choosing it over the sequel.
